Cucurbitaria berberidis CBS 394.84 is a species of ascomycete fungus belonging to the family Cucurbitariaceae. It is a saprobic fungus, meaning it feeds on decaying organic matter, and is commonly found on the dead branches and stems of barberry (Berberis) plants.

The fungus produces dark-colored, globose to irregular-shaped fruiting bodies called perithecia, which are embedded in the host plant's tissue. These perithecia contain asci, the spore-bearing structures, which release ascospores that aid in the dispersal and reproduction of the fungus.

Morphologically, the fungus is characterized by its dark brown to black perithecia, which can reach up to 0.5 mm in diameter, and the presence of septate, dark-colored ascospores within the asci. The ascospores are typically fusiform (spindle-shaped) and measure approximately 20-30 Î¼m in length.

Cucurbitaria berberidis CBS 394.84 is an important species for researchers studying the diversity and ecology of saprobic fungi associated with woody plant hosts, particularly in the Berberis genus.
